posts.cooked:
I continuously see these command loop overruns errors, and usually I would ignore them, but now with my addition of infusing vision into the robots odometry, I have a slight feeling that it is effecting the performance of my vision. I tried reducing the amount of logs I have, but I still have 0.3 second periodic cycles, which is more than 10x the usual 0.02s.

Ill also list the issue I am having with my vision here as well. Whenever I have the robot on blocks, and the cameras see the target it updates the pose well on Field2D, but when I start moving the target, it updates the position of the robot every slowly.

GitHub: GitHub - MiddletonRobotics/FRCMinotaur2025

image 1573×1113 51 KB

image 1573×1113 51 KB

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
If the loop overrun is consistently caused by your CommandSwerveDrivetrain.periodic() , I would zoom into your addPoseData() function. I see an array sort (of which the sorted array is never used) and two calls to visionManager.getUnreadResults(poseHistory) , each of which allocates a separate array (and looks very expensive, I see a lot of allocations).

I also don’t see anything preventing your poseHistory from growing to infinity? Which is going to increase the processing cost of the function over time.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: If @bhall-ctre suggestions don’t completely fix your problem, then I suggest VisualVM . I’ve used it on robot and non-robot programs with great effectiveness.

link_counts.title: Profiling with VisualVM — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: Thank you for the suggestion. When I am back in the lab tommorrow morning I will look into it further

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
The pose moving in slowly when on blocks makes sense to me. The drivetrain is incorporating wheel odometry into the pose estimation, and if they’re not moving that information goes into the data. And your standard deviations for trusting the drivetrain are probably tighter than those on vision. If you gave vision absurdly low values (0.0001 ?) for x/y std deviation it’d probably update closer to real-time when you move the target around.

And it probably does not need to be said but you wouldn’t want to run the robot the way. Just on blocks!
Yeah thats fair enough. I am not very educated with how pose estimation works beacuse this is the first time we are implementing a good version of it

Still have minor loop overruns, they seem to be only in SmartDashboard and telopInit. TeleopInit Im guessing is because I have a lot of commands?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: if I’m reading your code right, you have a blocking motor configure call in teleop init, which could cause a minor overrun.

Thank you for this. After removing the Arrays.sort to be able to filter the poseHistory, and some other changes to other subsystems I don’t have loop overruns as often (only get them when vision targets enabled). I will look further with VisualVM tomorrow to she what other things can be changed

suggested_topics.title: C++ OpenCV Namespace Intellisense Errors
suggested_topics.excerpt: Sounds like an Intellisense bug. I don’t think we can do anything about it. I personally don’t use the Microsoft C++ extension intellisense, but use clangd instead, which seems to be more robust.
